Erythrasma manifests as thin, atrophic, finely wrinkled pink-brown plaques in the intertriginous areas, such as the axillae or inguinal or gluteal folds, or less commonly in the interdigital or inframammary regions. The skin is often described as having “cigarette paper” appearance. A Wood lamp evaluation reveals a soft coral-red or pink fluorescence, as
in this patient with interdigital erythrasma.

Treatment is with oral or topical erythromycin (preferred for localized disease). Typical skin findings plus fluorescence with Wood lamp illumination confirms the diagnosis; additional testing is not needed.

Intertrigo is an inflammatory skin disease that involves the axillae, inframammary, and inguinal folds.

Diagnosis is frequently made on clinical grounds alone, but a potassium hydroxide preparation can show spores and pseudohyphae. Scabies infestation is characterized by intensely pruritic, crusted papules, nodules, and burrows that develop in the interdigital spaces, wrists, ankles, breasts, periumbilical area, and genitals.
